E. To cooperate with municipal or regional planning commissions and other agencies or groups to further the local planning program and to assure
harmonious and integrated planning for the area. (Ord. 78-21, 11-7-1978; amd. 2001 Code)
2-1-4: SUBDIVISION PLATS:
Following the adoption of the comprehensive plan in the manner prescribed in this chapter, no map or plat of any subdivision presented for record,
affecting land within the corporate limits of the village or in territory not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles from such limits and not included in any
other municipality, shall be entitled to record or shall be valid unless reviewed by the planning and zoning commission for conformity with appropriate
ordinances and requirements applicable to the comprehensive plan. (Ord. 78-21, 11-7-1978; amd. 2001 Code)
2-1-5: INFORMATION PROVIDED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 59/338
The village clerk shall furnish the planning and zoning commission, for its consideration, a copy of all ordinances and plans relative to improvements of any
nature. (Ord. 78-21, 11-7-1978; amd. 2001 Code)
2-1-6: COMPENSATION:
All members of the commission shall serve without compensation; except, that the members may be reimbursed for necessary expenses as may be fixed
from time to time by the village board as provided for in the appropriation ordinance. (Ord. 78-21, 11-7-1978)
2-1-7: ASSISTANCE:
The planning and zoning commission may, at the discretion of the village board, employ necessary clerical and technical services whose salaries, wages
and other necessary expenses shall be provided for by adequate appropriations made by the village board of trustees from public funds. (Ord. 78-21, 11-7-
1978; amd. 2001 Code)
Chapter 2
HISTORICAL PRESERVATION COMMISSION
(Rep. by Ord. 2005-12, 7-26-2005)
Chapter 3
EMERGENCY SERVICES AND DISASTER AGENCY
2-3-1: AGENCY CREATED; COMPOSITION:
There is hereby created the village emergency services and disaster agency to prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate injury or damage resulting from
disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage, or other hostile action, or from natural or manmade disaster, in accordance with "The Illinois Emergency
Management Agency Act"1. This emergency services and disaster agency shall consist of the coordinator and such additional members as may be
selected by the coordinator. (Ord. 76-03, 2-17-1976; amd. 2001 Code)
2-3-2: COORDINATOR:
A. Appointment; Term: The coordinator of the village emergency services and disaster agency shall be appointed by the village president and shall serve
until removed by same.
B. Powers And Duties: The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training and operation of the emergency
services and disaster agency, subject to the direction and control of the village president as provided by statute.
C. Vacancy In Office: In the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability to serve as the coordinator, the village president or any person designated
by him, shall be and act as coordinator until a new appointment is made as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 76-03, 2-17-1976)
2-3-3: FUNCTIONS:
The village emergency services and disaster agency shall perform such emergency services and disaster agency functions within the village as shall be
prescribed in and by the state emergency management agency plan and program prepared by the governor, and such orders, rules and regulations as
may be promulgated by the governor and, in addition, shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid
agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality or quasi-municipality entered into as provided by "The State Emergency Management Agency
Act". (Ord. 76-03, 2-17-1976; amd. 2001 Code)
2-3-4: SERVICE AS MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM:
A. Members Designated: All or any members of the village emergency services and disaster agency organization may be designated as members of a
mobile support team created by the director of the state emergency management agency as provided by law. (Ord. 76-03, 2-17-1976; amd. 2001
Code)
B. Team Leader: The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated by the coordinator of the village emergency services and disaster agency
organization.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 60/338
C. Compensation; Powers And Duties: Any member of a mobile support team who is a village employee or officer while serving on call to duty by the
governor, or the state director, shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights and immunities incident to such employment or
office. Any such member who is not a paid officer or employee of the village, while so serving, shall receive from the state reasonable compensation as
provided by law. (Ord. 76-03, 2-17-1976)
2-3-5: AGREEMENTS WITH OTHER POLITICAL SUBDIVISIONS:
The coordinator of emergency services and disaster agency may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other cities or political subdivisions of the state, but
no such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the village president and by the state director of emergency management agency. (Ord.
76-03, 2-17-1976; amd. 2001 Code)
2-3-6: EMERGENCY ACTION:
If the governor proclaims that a disaster emergency exists in the event of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the state of
a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or from manmade or natural disaster, it shall be the duty of the village emergency
services and disaster agency to cooperate fully with the state emergency management agency and with the governor in the exercise of emergency powers
as provided by law. (Ord. 76-03, 2-17-1976; amd. 2001 Code)
2-3-7: COMPENSATION:
Members of the emergency services and disaster agency who are paid employees or officers of the village, if called for training by the state director of
emergency management agency, shall receive for the time spent in such training the same rate of pay as is attached to the position held; members who
are not such village employees or officers shall receive for such training time such compensation as may be established by the village president. (Ord. 76-
03, 2-17-1976; amd. 2001 Code)
2-3-8: REIMBURSEMENT BY STATE:
The village treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund, any reimbursement by the state to the village for expenses incident to training
members of the emergency services and disaster agency as prescribed by the state director of emergency management agency, compensation for
services and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside the village in response to a call by the governor or state director of
emergency management agency, as provided by law, and any other reimbursement made by the state incident to emergency services and disaster agency
activities as provided by law. (Ord. 76-03, 2-17-1976; amd. 2001 Code)
2-3-9: PURCHASES AND EXPENDITURES:
A. Authority Of Village President: The village president may, on recommendation of the village coordinator of emergency services and disaster agency,
authorize any purchase or contracts necessary to place the village in a position to combat effectively any disaster resulting from the explosion of any
nuclear or other bomb or missile, and to protect the public health and safety, protect property, and provide emergency assistance to victims in the case
of such disaster, or from manmade or natural disaster. (Ord. 76-03, 2-17-1976)
B. Authority Of Coordinator: In the event of enemy caused or other disaster, the village coordinator of emergency services and disaster agency is
authorized, on behalf of the village, to procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for such purposes in view of the
exigency without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to village contracts or obligations, as authorized
by "The State Emergency Management Agency Act"; provided, that if the village board of trustees meets at such time, the village president shall act
subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body. (Ord. 76-03, 2-17-1976; amd. 2001 Code)
2-3-10: OATH OF OFFICE:
Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the village emergency services and disaster agency organization shall, before entering upon his duties,
subscribe to the following oath, which shall be filed with the coordinator:
I, , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the
Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions, and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic;
that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I
am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that
advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the
village of Glen Carbon emergency services and disaster agency organization, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or
organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence.
(Ord. 76-03, 2-17-1976)
2-3-11: LOCAL EMERGENCY ACTION:
The village president or, upon his absence or inability to act, the coordinator of emergency services and disaster agency, is authorized and designated to
proclaim that a disaster emergency exists in the event of the occurrence of a major disaster resulting from hostile action or from manmade or natural
disaster, and it shall be the duty of the village emergency services and disaster agency to cooperate fully with the village president or coordinator in the
exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. (Ord. 79-06, 7-17-1979)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 61/338
2-3-12: OFFICE:
The village president is authorized to designate space in a village building, or elsewhere as may be provided for by the village president, for the village
emergency services and disaster agency as its office. (Ord. 76-03, 2-17-1976)
2-3-13: APPROPRIATION; LEVY OF TAXES:
The village president may make an appropriation for emergency services and disaster agency purposes in the manner provided by law, and may levy in
addition, for emergency services and disaster agency purposes only, in the manner provided by law. (Ord. 76-03, 2-17-1976; amd. 2001 Code)
Chapter 4
BOARD OF POLICE COMMISSIONERS
2-4-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT; TERMS OF OFFICE:
There is hereby created and established a board of police commissioners in and for the village, as provided by law, which shall consist of three (3)
members appointed by the president with the consent of the board of trustees. Within thirty (30) days after 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1-1 et seq.,
becomes effective in the village, the president shall appoint the first members of the board of police commissioners. One of the members shall be
appointed to serve until the end of the current municipal year, another to serve until the end of the municipal year next ensuing and the third to serve until
the end of the municipal year second next ensuing. Thereafter, each member so appointed shall serve for a term of three (3) years and until his successor
has been appointed and has qualified, pursuant to state law. (Ord. 81-11, 5-19-1981; amd. 2001 Code)
2-4-2: AUTHORITY REGARDING POLICE OFFICERS:
A. All duly appointed officers shall be subject to the board of police commissioners, pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1-1 et seq., for
disciplinary termination purposes as provided by applicable law.
B. The board of police commissioners shall have charge of all original appointments to the police department and shall conduct and hold all entrance and
promotional examinations in the manner required by law. (Ord. 81-11, 5-19-1981; amd. 2001 Code)
2-4-3: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The board of police commissioners shall operate and promulgate rules and discharge the responsibilities as provided in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-
2.1-1 et seq., as amended. (Ord. 81-11, 5-19-1981; amd. 2001 Code)
Chapter 5
POLICE PENSION FUND AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
2-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
The terms used in this chapter, for the purpose of this chapter, shall have the following meanings, except when the context requires otherwise:
BOARD: The board of trustees of the police pension fund of the village of Glen Carbon, Illinois.
CHILD OR CHILDREN: Includes a police officer's natural children and his legally adopted children; provided, that adopted children shall be eligible for
benefits only if the judicial proceedings for adoption were commenced at least one year prior to the death or disability of the police officer and in any event
prior to his attainment of age fifty (50).
CREDITABLE SERVICE: Shall be computed as set forth in the Illinois pension code1.
DEATH BENEFITS: A. Upon the death of a police officer entitled to a pension under the provisions of this chapter, his or her surviving spouse or his or her
surviving minor children dependant because of physical or mental disability regardless of age or dependant because of age, or his surviving dependant
parent or parents if such there be, shall be entitled to the pension to which the police officer was then entitled.
B. Upon the death of a police officer who has at least twenty (20) years of creditable service, or upon the death of a police officer who retired from
service with at least twenty (20) years of creditable service, whether his death occurs before or after he has attained age fifty (50), or before or after
his application for retirement on pension, the pension to which the descendant would have been entitled, had he lived and applied for pension as of
the date of his death, shall be paid to his dependents as provided upon death of a pensioner in subsection A of this definition.
DISABILITY PENSIONS: Disability pensions in the amount set forth in the Illinois pension code2 shall be payable to a disabled police officer upon the
conditions therein set forth.
GENDER: The term "police officer" includes policewoman, and words importing the masculine gender import the feminine gender, unless such
construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intention of the context.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 62/338
PENSION, AMOUNT: The amount of the pension to be received by any police officer shall be computed in accordance with the provisions of the Illinois
pension code.
PERSONS EXCLUDED: A. Part-time police officers, special police officers, night watchmen, temporary employees, dispatchers, or so called "auxiliary
police officers" specially appointed to aid or direct traffic at or near schools or public functions, or to aid in civil defense, municipal parking lot attendants,
clerks or other civilian employees of a police department who perform clerical duties exclusively.
B. Any police officer who fails to pay the salary payments or deductions hereinafter defined, computed from the date the village became subject to
article 3 of the Illinois pension code3 by attaining a population of five thousand (5,000), and continuing, during his entire service as a police officer. A
police officer who is reappointed shall, before being declared eligible to participate in the pension fund, repay to the fund as required by 40 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/3-124, any refund received pursuant to said section.
POLICE OFFICER, POLICE OFFICERS, MEMBER OF THE POLICE FORCE: A. Any person who:
1. Is heretofore or hereafter appointed to the police force of the Glen Carbon police department and sworn and commissioned to perform police
duties; and
2. Is found upon examination of a duly licensed physician or physicians selected by the board to be physically and mentally fit to perform the duties
of a police officer; and
3. Within three (3) months after receiving his first appointment, and of reappointment, within three (3) months thereafter, makes written application to
come under the provisions of article 3, of the Illinois pension code4.
B. Police officers serving initial probationary periods, if otherwise eligible, shall be police officers within the meaning of this section. (Ord. 81-20, 9-15-
1981; amd. 2001 Code)
2-5-2: BOARD AND FUND CREATED:
There is hereby created and established the board of trustees of the police pension fund of the village and the Glen Carbon police pension fund. (Ord. 81-
20, 9-15-1981)
2-5-3: COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT AND ELECTION OF MEMBERS:
The board shall be composed of five (5) members, who shall be residents of the village. Two (2) members of the board shall be appointed by the president
of the village board of trustees. The third and fourth members of the board shall be elected from the regular police force by the active members thereof.
The fifth member shall be elected by and from among the beneficiaries of the fund. (Ord. 81-20, 9-15-1981)
2-5-4: TERMS OF OFFICE:
One of the board members appointed by the mayor shall serve for one year beginning on the second Tuesday in May 1981. The other appointed member
shall serve for two (2) years beginning on the same date. The successors of the appointed members of the board shall serve for two (2) years each or until
their successors are appointed and qualified. (Ord. 81-20, 9-15-1981; amd. 2001 Code)
2-5-5: ELECTION OF BOARD MEMBERS:
A. Biennial Election: The election provided for in this chapter for elected board members shall be held biennially on the third Monday in April at such place
or places in the village and under the Australian ballot system and such other regulations as shall be prescribed by the appointed members of the
board. (Ord. 81-20, 9-15-1981; amd. 2001 Code)
B. Voting: All members of the regular Glen Carbon police force shall be entitled to vote only for the police force members of the board. All beneficiaries of
legal age shall be entitled to vote only for the member chosen from among the beneficiaries. No person shall be entitled to cast more than one ballot at
such election. The members shall be elected for a term of two (2) years beginning on the second Tuesday of the first May after such election. (Ord. 81-
20, 9-15-1981)
2-5-6: VACANCIES ON BOARD:
Upon the death, resignation or inability to act of any member of the board elected under this chapter, his successor shall be elected for the unexpired term
at a special election to be called by the board and conducted in the same manner as the regular biennial election. (Ord. 81-20, 9-15-1981; amd. 2001
Code)
2-5-7: ORGANIZATION:
A. Meetings: The board shall hold regular quarterly meetings on the second Tuesday of July, October, January and April annually and special meetings as
called by the president.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 63/338
B. Officers: At the regular July meeting, the board shall select from its members a president, vice president, secretary and assistant secretary to serve for
the period of one year and until their respective successors are elected and qualified. The vice president of the board shall perform the duties of the
president during any vacancy in that office, or during such time as the president is absent from the village, or if for any other reason is disqualified or by
reason of illness or causes is unable to perform his duties. The assistant secretary shall act for the secretary whenever necessary to discharge the
functions of such office. (Ord. 81-20, 9-15-1981)
2-5-8: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board shall have those powers and duties set forth in the Illinois pension code generally, and particularly those powers set forth in 40 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/3-132 through 5/3-140.1 thereof. (Ord. 81-20, 9-15-1981; amd. 2001 Code)
2-5-9: COMPENSATION:
Members of the board shall receive no money or monies from a pension fund as salary for services performed as members of such board. (Ord. 81-20, 9-
15-1981)
2-5-10: PENSION PROVISIONS:
A. Retirement: Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as requiring the retirement at age fifty (50) of any police officer who is capable of
performing his duties. (Ord. 81-20, 9-15-1981)
B. Police Officers Killed In Line Of Duty: There shall be paid to the spouse, minor children, or dependant parents of a police officer who is killed in the line
of duty, those benefits in such case made and provided under the Illinois pension code.
C. Financing Pension Payments: The cost of providing the pension benefits required to be paid by the village under the provisions of the Illinois pension
code and this chapter shall be financed by the levy of a tax pursuant to the provisions of 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-125. (Ord. 81-20, 9-15-1981;
amd. 2001 Code)
2-5-11: COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAW:
It is the intention of the corporate authorities that the provisions of this chapter shall in all respects comply with and be consistent with the provisions of the
Illinois pension code, and this chapter shall be construed so as to give it that effect. (Ord. 81-20, 9-15-1981)
Chapter 6
HISTORICAL AND MUSEUM COMMISSION
2-6-1: MUSEUM ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established within the village of Glen Carbon a historical museum to be known as the "Glen Carbon Heritage Museum". (Ord. 2014-1, 1-
14-2014)
2-6-2: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a historical and museum commission in and for the village to be known as the Glen Carbon historical and museum
commission. (Ord. 2014-1, 1-14-2014)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 2019-17 - HISTORICAL AND MUSEUM COMMISSION. Go to new ordinance.
2-6-3: MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; CHAIRPERSON; ORGANIZATION:
The Glen Carbon historical and museum commission (the "commission") shall consist of nine (9) voting members appointed by the mayor with the advice
and consent of the village board and with the ability to solicit the expertise of people engaged in fields such as history, education, architecture, urban
planning, archaeology, real estate, museums, art and law. The commission may annually elect a chairman, vice chairman and secretary from its own
voting members. The commission may adopt such rules, regulations and guidelines, as it deems necessary, to carry out the duties imposed by this
chapter. (Ord. 2015-9, 3-24-2015)
2-6-4: TERMS OF OFFICE:
Voting members of the commission shall serve for terms not to exceed three (3) years, being eligible for reappointment as shall be specified by the mayor
with the advice and consent of the village board. The appointments shall be so arranged that the term of at least one member shall expire each year and
his successor shall be appointed in like manner for a term of three (3) years. (Ord. 2014-1, 1-14-2014)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 64/338
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 2019-17 - HISTORICAL AND MUSEUM COMMISSION. Go to new ordinance.
2-6-5: DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION:
The duties of the commission shall be as follows:
A. Recommend an annual budget to be approved by the Glen Carbon village board;
B. Create a database and retrieval system suitable for use in planning and to review decision making and public information programs;
C. Create one written set of guidelines, rules and procedures for the handling of artifacts, relics, including, but not limited to, memorabilia and historical
items;
D. Involve departments of the village government and interested members of the community as much as possible in its work, and to encourage
complementary activity with schools and other agencies and organizations;
E. Carry out a public information program, including the preparation of appropriate exhibits and publications to be either distributed free of charge or sold;
F. Recommend to the mayor and village board any additional measures to protect and identify those portions of the village or properties and structures that
have significant historical, architectural or aesthetic features;
G. When necessary, hold public hearings in designating any area, place, building or structure, or any other object, as a historical landmark;
H. Meet on a monthly basis, and as needed with proper notice, at a time and place to be determined by the commission;
I. Solicit, accept or apply for funds to be used in the furtherance of the mission of the Yanda Log Cabin, museum or other assigned venues by the village
board;
J. Assist the museum coordinator with the day to day operations of the Glen Carbon Heritage Museum and its volunteers; assist the museum coordinator
with the operations of the Glen Carbon Yanda Log Cabin and other venues assigned by the village board;
K. Establish a mission statement including the Glen Carbon Yanda Log Cabin, the Glen Carbon Heritage Museum and other venues assigned by the
village board;
L. Recommend to the mayor and village board the adoption of ordinances designating areas, places, buildings, structures, or other objects having
significant historical, architectural or aesthetic features as historical landmarks, if they qualify as such;
M. Recommend the appointment and approval to the Glen Carbon village board all persons to be hired as employees of the museum, if any; however, any
employees of the museum, including the museum coordinator, shall be supervised by the village's building and zoning administrator. (Ord. 2014-1, 1-
14-2014)
2-6-6: COMPENSATION:
The members of the commission shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 2014-1, 1-14-2014)
2-6-7: FACILITIES FOR MEETINGS AND STORAGE OF RECORDS AND ARTIFACTS:
The village shall provide a meeting place in the village hall or some other designated village owned facility together with the necessary filing space for
records and necessary space to display artifacts, relics and memorabilia. (Ord. 2014-1, 1-14-2014)
2-6-8: FUNDS:
The village board is hereby authorized to accept grants from the state or federal government, and public or private gifts, and/or fundraising events, for
historic preservation purposes. The village board shall advise the commission of the availability of such funds, and the commission shall recommend the
manner in which such funds shall be expended. The village is hereby authorized to appoint the commission as its agent to accept and administer grants
and gifts for historic preservation and museum purposes and to establish ownership of relics, artifacts and any other memorabilia. (Ord. 2014-1, 1-14-
2014)
2-6-9: CRITERIA FOR DESIGNATING HISTORIC LANDMARKS:
The commission shall consider the following criteria in designating areas, places, buildings, structures, and other objects as landmarks:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 65/338
A. Its character, interest or value as part of the development, heritage, or other cultural characteristics of the community, county, state or nation;
B. Its location as a site of a significant local, county, state or national event;
C. Its identification with a person, corporation or organization that significantly contributed to the development of the community, county, state or nation;
D. Its exemplification of the cultural, economic, social, political, or historical heritage of the community;
E. Its portrayal in the environment of a group of people in an era of history characterized by a distinctive architectural or cultural style;
F. Its identification as the work of a master builder, designer, or architect whose individual work has influenced the development of the community;
G. Its embodiment of distinguishing characteristics of an architectural style valuable for the study of a period, type, method of construction, or use of
indigenous materials; and
H. Its establishment of a sense of time and place unique to the village. (Ord. 2014-1, 1-14-2014)
2-6-10: PROCEDURE TO ESTABLISH HISTORICAL LANDMARK:
The following procedures must be followed to establish a historical landmark:
A. Request For Historic Designation: Any person, organization, or association may request, by letter to the commission, that an area, place, building,
structure or object be designated as a landmark. The commission may also initiate the designation of any area, place, building, structure or object as a
landmark.
B. Notice And Hearing: The commission shall, after the establishment of preliminary boundaries for any proposed historic area, place, building or structure
or object, set a time and place for one or more public hearings on the merits of designating the defined area as the landmark. The commission shall
send notification by registered mail to all owners of record of property within the defined area not less than fifteen (15) days, nor more than thirty (30)
days, prior to the date of the hearing. In the case of a single place, building or structure, only the owner of record shall be notified. The notice shall set
forth the boundaries of the area under consideration, the reasons for its being considered for designation, and the date, time and place of the public
hearing. In addition, the secretary of the commission shall have a notice of such hearing published in a newspaper of general circulation in the village
not less than fifteen (15) days, nor more than thirty (30) days, prior to the date of the hearing. Notice of such hearing shall also be given to the mayor,
building and zoning administrator, chairman of the zoning board of appeals, chairman of the planning and zoning commission and to the village board.
The hearing shall be conducted by the commission, and all interested persons shall be given an opportunity to be heard in person, by counsel, or by
correspondence.
C. Commission Recommendations: After hearing testimony and considering any and all other evidence submitted on the issue, the commission shall make
its recommendations to the village board.
D. Village Board Decision: The village board shall then, within a reasonable time after receiving the recommendations of the commission, either accept or
reject the recommendations. In the event that the village board should accept only part and reject part of the recommendations, then the village board
shall refer the recommendations back to the commission for its concurrence. If all of the recommendations are accepted by the village board, or if some
of the recommendations are accepted by the village board, referred to the commission, and the commission concurs with the amendments made by
the village board, then the village board shall, by ordinance, establish the boundaries of said designated area, place, building, structure or object as a
"historical landmark". (Ord. 2014-1, 1-14-2014)
Chapter 7
COMMUNITY EVENTS COMMITTEE
2-7-1: COMMITTEE ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a committee in and for the Village to be known as the Glen Carbon Community Events Committee. (Ord. 2007-7, 3-27-2007)
2-7-2: MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; ORGANIZATION:
The Glen Carbon Community Events Committee (the "committee") shall consist of eleven (11) members appointed by the Mayor with the advice and
consent of the Village Board. Members shall consist of those members duly appointed by the Mayor. The members shall be appointed in August of each
year. The members may elect a Chairperson, Vice Chairperson, Secretary and Committee Treasurer from the duly appointed members. (Ord. 2019-04, 1-
22-2019)
2-7-3: TERMS OF OFFICE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 66/338
Members of the committee shall serve for terms not to exceed three (3) years, being eligible for reappointment as shall be specified by the Mayor with the
advice and consent of the Village Board. The appointments shall be so arranged that the term of at least one member shall expire each year and his
successor shall be appointed in like manner for a term of three (3) years. (Ord. 2007-7, 3-27-2007)
2-7-4: DUTIES OF THE COMMITTEE:
The duties of the "committee" shall be as follows: (Ord. 2016-1, 1-12-2016)
A. Develop an annual budget for each community event to be recommended to and approved by the Glen Carbon Village Board; said budget for all events
shall be submitted to the Finance and Administrative Committee by September 15 of each year; any substantial change (10 percent or more) must go
back to the Village Board for approval; (Ord. 2019-04, 1-22-2019)
B. Working list of vendors for homecoming shall be provided to the Village Board for approval by February 1 and August 15 for GlenFest or as soon as
determined, and will be updated monthly for approval by the Board. Any early applications for vendors shall be submitted upon receipt. A "vendor" is
defined as a person or entity that sells or promotes a product or service at a community event (excludes the Village);
C. Any issues during the planning of community events, including issues with potential vendors (i.e., contract terms, conflicts, etc.) are to be reported in
writing as soon as reasonably possible, but no later than two (2) weeks, to the Village Administrator and Village Board liaison. Village Administrator and
Village Board liaison to jointly investigate issues and report said issues to Village Board for discussion and any action if necessary;
D. After the first June Board meeting is concluded, Community Events Committee has authority to enforce the Village Board approved rules and
regulations for the homecoming;
E. After the first September Board meeting is concluded, Community Events Committee has authority to enforce the Village Board approved rules and
regulations for the GlenFest;
F. At conclusion of event, Community Events Committee submits final report including financials and any operational issues with vendors, citizens, etc., to
the Village Board. The Village Board liaison and Village Administrator will jointly investigate outstanding issues and report findings to the Village Board
for discussion and any action if necessary;
G. All rules and regulations for the homecoming and GlenFest are to be reviewed annually by the Village Board for approval in March;
H. Involve departments of the Village government and interested members of the community as much as possible in its work, and to encourage
complementary activity with civic organizations, local businesses, schools and other agencies and organizations;
I. Carry out a public information and advertisement program for the community event;
J. Meet on a monthly basis, or as needed with proper notice, at a time and place to be determined by the committee;
K. Present any and all proposals and contracts for any community event to the Village Board for approval; and
L. The Community Events Committee is an advisory committee to the Village Board and will take other appropriate and reasonable actions to make the
community event a successful event.
At this time, it is contemplated that the committee will work on two (2) community events. The committee may, however, from time to time recommend
additional community events to be held within the Village, except for events that take place at the Glen Carbon Yanda Log Cabin or the Glen Carbon
Heritage Museum. Events at those venues shall remain the primary responsibility of the Village Commission Board responsible for those venues. (Ord.
2016-1, 1-12-2016)
2-7-5: COMPENSATION:
The members of the committee shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 2007-7, 3-27-2007)
2-7-6: FACILITIES FOR MEETINGS:
The Village shall provide a meeting place in the Village Hall or some other designated Village owned facility. (Ord. 2007-7, 3-27-2007)
Chapter 8
GARDENING LANDSCAPING ENHANCING NATURE COMMITTEE
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 67/338
2-8-1: COMMITTEE ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a "gardening landscaping enhancing nature" committee in and for the village to be known as the GLEN Committee. (Ord.
2005-22, 12-13-2005)
2-8-2: VILLAGE LIAISON ESTABLISHED:
The mayor shall appoint a member of the village board of trustees to serve as a liaison between the Glen Carbon village board and GLEN committee.
(Ord. 2005-22, 12-13-2005)
2-8-3: MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; CHAIRPERSON; ORGANIZATION:
The GLEN committee (the "committee") shall consist of seven (7) voting members appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the village board
and with the ability to solicit the expertise of people engaged in fields such as horticulture, gardening, education, architecture, urban landscape planning,
art and law. At the first meeting of the GLEN committee in May of each year, the voting members of the GLEN committee will elect from the group of voting
members a chairperson and a vice chairperson of the GLEN committee. (Ord. 2005-22, 12-13-2005)
2-8-4: TERMS OF OFFICE:
Voting members of the committee shall serve for terms not to exceed three (3) years, being eligible for reappointment as shall be specified by the mayor
with the advice and consent of the village board. The appointments shall be so arranged that the term of at least one member shall expire each year and
his successor shall be appointed in like manner for a term of three (3) years. (Ord. 2005-22, 12-13-2005)
2-8-5: DUTIES OF THE COMMITTEE:
The duties of the committee shall be as follows:
A. Recommend to the mayor and village board any additional measures to preserve and beautify those portions of village owned property and structures
that have significant or aesthetic features, including, but not limited to, the Glen Carbon Village Farm;
B. Prepare an annual budget that will include recommendations for a maintenance plan for the plantings and shrubbery on village owned property. The
budget shall be presented to the mayor for approval with the advice and consent of the village of Glen Carbon board of trustees and shall be approved
during the first meeting in May each year. Maintenance costs shall be paid out of the committee's annual budget;
C. Review landscape developmental plans and make suggestions to the planning commission and/or village board that are consistent with the applicable
village ordinances. Any suggestions should be reported to the building and zoning administrator on or before the second and fourth Wednesday each
month;
D. Solicit and involve interested members of the community as much as possible in its work, and to encourage complementary activity with schools and
other agencies and organizations;
E. Meet twice per month, and as needed with proper notice, at a time and place to be determined by the committee. (Ord. 2005-22, 12-13-2005)
2-8-6: COMPENSATION:
The members of the committee shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 2005-22, 12-13-2005)
2-8-7: FACILITIES FOR MEETINGS:
The village shall provide a meeting place for the committee. (Ord. 2005-22, 12-13-2005)
2-8-8: FUNDS:
The village board is hereby authorized to accept grants from the state or federal government, and public or private gifts, and/or fundraising events, for
beautification or preservation purposes. The village board shall advise the committee of the availability of such funds, and the committee shall recommend
the manner in which such funds shall be expended. (Ord. 2005-22, 12-13-2005)
Chapter 9
RESIDENTS' ADVISORY BOARD
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 68/338
2-9-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED; GOALS:
There is hereby established a Glen Carbon residents' advisory board. The goal for this board is to encourage ideas and suggestions in an open and
inclusive environment so that the village can maintain and improve the quality of life for its residents. (Ord. 2006-1, 1-10-2006)
2-9-2: MEMBERSHIP:
The Glen Carbon residents' advisory board (the "board") shall consist of seven (7) voting members age twenty one (21) years or older that have resided in
the village for at least one year. Five (5) members of the board will be appointed via the at large selection process and two (2) members of the board will
be appointed by the mayor. (Ord. 2006-1, 1-10-2006)
2-9-3: VOLUNTEERS; AT LARGE SELECTION:
The village will be divided into five (5) geographically equal areas based primarily on population. The residents' advisory board map will be available for
inspection during normal business hours in the Glen Carbon building and zoning administrator's office. The board will appoint one voting member from
each of the five (5) geographic areas of the village. To serve on the board, an eligible resident needs to provide proof of residency and to fill out an
application at the village hall by the last business day of March in each even numbered year (e.g., March 31, 2006). If only one resident from any given
area volunteers to serve on the board, that person will be appointed the member from that area. If more than one resident applies from a certain area, then
the member from that area will be objectively selected by pulling one name out of a hat during a date established by the village clerk in April. Each at large
member will be appointed during the first board of trustees meeting in May during each even numbered year. Vacancies among the at large members of
the board will be filled using the method established in this section with the deadline for applications set by the board. (Ord. 2006-1, 1-10-2006)
2-9-4: APPOINTMENT; CHAIRPERSON; VICE CHAIRPERSON:
The remaining two (2) voting members of the board will be appointed chairperson and vice chairperson and will be appointed by the mayor with the advice
and consent of the village board. These appointments will be made during the first board of trustees meeting in May. The two (2) appointed members may
reside in any of the five (5) areas but not the same area. Accordingly, at no time will there ever be more than two (2) residents from the same area on the
board. Vacancies among the appointed members of the board will be filled using the method established in this section. (Ord. 2006-1, 1-10-2006)
2-9-5: TERMS OF OFFICE:
The five (5) at large voting members of the board shall serve for two (2) year terms starting on May 1 of each even numbered year, being eligible for
reappointment as provided for in section 2-9-3 of this chapter. The two (2) appointed voting members shall serve as chairperson and vice chairperson for a
four (4) year term consecutive with that of the mayor's office. The mayor may reappoint any appointed member at the end of each term in accordance with
section 2-9-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 2006-1, 1-10-2006)
2-9-6: MEETINGS:
The board will be subject to the Illinois open meetings act, thus, all of the meetings will be properly noticed and open to the public. The board will meet at
least quarterly or additionally, as the majority of the board deems necessary. Meetings will take place either at the village hall, community and senior
center, or the new public safety facility. All agenda and meeting minutes will also be sent via mail or e-mail to all homeowner association presidents, to the
Edwardsville-Glen Carbon chamber of commerce or its successor, and posted on the village website. (Ord. 2006-1, 1-10-2006)
2-9-7: DUTIES OF THE BOARD:
The duties of the committee shall be as follows:
A. To review issues assigned to it by the village board and mayor and other issues that the board deems appropriate for consideration.
B. To make independent, objective "advisory" recommendations to the village board and mayor on issues that impact village residents and businesses.
C. To schedule forums on topics of interest to the residents and businesses of Glen Carbon. (Ord. 2006-1, 1-10-2006)
2-9-8: COMPENSATION:
The members of the board shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 2006-1, 1-10-2006)
2-9-9: FACILITIES FOR MEETINGS:
The village shall provide a meeting place for the board. (Ord. 2006-1, 1-10-2006)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 69/338

Title 3
BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
BUSINESS REGISTRATION
3-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter the terms defined in this section have the meanings given them:
BUSINESS: Any business operated by a sole proprietor, partnership, corporation or organization within the village of Glen Carbon.
OWNERS: Any sole proprietor, partners, corporation or organization.
VILLAGE: Village of Glen Carbon, Madison County, Illinois. (Ord. 2007-24, 12-11-2007)
3-1-2: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
All businesses domiciled in the village or conducting business from a location or locations within the village must register said business with the village.
(Ord. 2007-24, 12-11-2007)
3-1-3: FILING:
All registrations shall be submitted by January 31 of each year to the village clerk. Businesses failing to register by this date shall be assessed a late filing
penalty of twenty five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 2007-24, 12-11-2007)
3-1-4: DURATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 71/338
A. Businesses must be registered during the month of January every year.
B. Registrations are effective for one year, beginning January 1 and terminating December 31 of each year.
C. The village clerk shall notify all registered businesses of registration expiration during the month of November. However, it is the obligation of each
business to renew its registration and failure to receive an expiration notification is not a defense for operating without a registration.
D. The village clerk shall issue a certificate of registration for each registered business. This certificate shall be posted in a prominent visible location in
each business at all times. (Ord. 2007-24, 12-11-2007)
3-1-5: REGISTRATION NOT ASSIGNABLE; UNLAWFUL USE:
No registration granted under the provisions of this chapter shall be assigned or transferred. Each registration is only valid for the person and business
named in the registration. (Ord. 2007-24, 12-11-2007)
3-1-6: LOCATION OF BUSINESS:
A. One Location Only; Separate Registration For Each Location: No license for the operation of a business or establishment in the village shall be
construed to permit the operation of a registered business or establishment in more than one location in the village; a separate registration shall be
required for each location of a registered establishment. For the purposes of this chapter, the existence of a single location shall be evidenced by the
fact that all buildings containing the principal or accessory uses shall be connected or shall be located on the same lot or parcel, shall be operated and
managed by the same person or owner, and shall be an establishment with the same classification.
B. Change Of Location: The location of any registered business or occupation or the location of any registered act may be changed; provided, that ten (10)
days' prior notice is given to the village clerk thereof. (Ord. 2007-24, 12-11-2007)
3-1-7: BUILDING AND PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
No registration shall be issued for the conduct of any business if the premises and building to be used for the purpose do not fully comply with all
applicable ordinances and regulations of the village and the state. (Ord. 2007-24, 12-11-2007)
3-1-8: NUISANCE BUSINESSES:
A. Prohibited Generally: No business or establishment, whether or not licensed, shall be so conducted or operated as to constitute a nuisance in fact; and
no building, vehicle, structure, yard, lot, premises, or part thereof, shall be used, kept, maintained, or operated in connection with any business or
establishment so as to occasion any nuisance, or so as to be dangerous to life or detrimental to health, welfare or safety of the public or any individual.
B. Unsafe Or Unhealthful Business:
1. No building or structure utilized, constructed, or maintained in connection with any business or occupation shall evidence an unsanitary, unsafe, or
dangerous condition.
2. No substance, matter, or thing of any kind whatever which shall be dangerous or detrimental to health, welfare or safety of the public or any
individual shall be allowed to exist in connection with any business or occupation or be used in any work or labor performed in the village. (Ord.
2007-24, 12-11-2007)
3-1-9: INSPECTIONS:
A. Inspections Authorized: Any authorized agent or employee of the village shall visit or cause to be visited the registrant or applicants for registrations
hereunder as often as shall be deemed necessary to assure compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
B. Entry Powers: Whenever inspections of the premises used for or in connection with the operation of a registered business or occupation are provided
for or required by ordinance, or are reasonably necessary to assure compliance with the provisions of any ordinance or regulation of the village, or to
detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the registrant or the person in charge of the premises to admit thereto for the purpose of making the
inspection any officer or employee of the village who is duly authorized to make such inspection at any reasonable time that such admission or entry is
requested.
C. Samples: Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably necessary to assure compliance with the provisions of any ordinance or
regulation, or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the registrant or the person in charge of the premises to give to any duly authorized
officer or employee of the village requesting the same sufficient samples of such material or commodity.
D. Failure To Permit Inspections: In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the president of the village board may revoke the license of any
owner or operator of a registered business in the village who refuses to permit any duly authorized officer or employee to make such inspection or to
take an adequate sample of said commodity, or who interferes with such officer or employee while in the performance of his duties. (Ord. 2007-24, 12-
11-2007)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 72/338
3-1-10: APPLICATION:
A. Each registration application shall be made to the village clerk in writing on a form provided by the village clerk, or as otherwise allowed by the village
clerk.
B. Each application will contain the following information:
1. Registration fee.
2. Type of business.
3. Business address and telephone number.
4. Date business started.
5. Name, mailing address and contact telephone number of each owner, partner or corporate officer.
6. Corporate address and contact name and telephone number (if any).
7. An after hours (emergency) contact name and telephone number.
8. Illinois business tax number.
9. Federal income tax number.
10. The numbers of any federal, state or county licenses or certificates held.
11. Approximate number of full time and part time employees.
12. Approximate number of agents.
13. Type and location of any toxic, flammable or hazardous materials stored or used at said location.
14. Alarm company information.
C. Every application for a food related business shall provide evidence of the required health certificates issued by the Madison County health department.
D. Significant changes to information submitted are to be reported as soon as possible and shall be done at no charge to the registrant. (Ord. 2007-24, 12-
11-2007)
3-1-11: SUSPENSION, REVOCATION AND APPEAL:
A. The mayor is hereby authorized to suspend or revoke a business registration thereby causing the cessation of business when:
1. The business operation constitutes a clear and present danger to the public safety, health or general welfare.
2. The registration application information is fraudulent, false or deceptive.
B. If a registration is suspended or revoked the business will be notified immediately either in person by an officer of the village or by phone. A follow up
written notice will be sent by certified mail. Both notifications will include the reason that caused the action. A suspension or revocation shall remain in
place until rescinded by the mayor or by a successful appeal to the Glen Carbon village board of trustees.
C. An appeal of the suspension must be requested by the registrant and is allowed at either:
1. The next regular scheduled village board meeting, or
2. A special meeting if the special meeting meets village ordinances and the business has been given at least three (3) days' notice or has waived the
three (3) day requirement.
D. The village attorney shall present the complaint and represent the village. The registrant is allowed council and has the right to submit evidence and
cross examine witnesses. A simple majority of the village board is required to rescind the suspension or revocation. In case of a tie, the mayor will cast
the deciding vote.
E. The village will keep an electronic record of the hearing. If either party requires a transcript that party shall pay the cost of the transcription.
F. Revocation of a business registration shall not preclude prosecution or imposition of other penalties for the violation of any other ordinance of the village.
(Ord. 2007-24, 12-11-2007)
3-1-12: PENALTY:
Any business in violation of this chapter shall be fined in an amount not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 2007-24, 12-11-2007)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 73/338
3-1-13: ENFORCEMENT OF OTHER ORDINANCES; DISCLAIMER:
Any business issued a registration must still comply with all other village ordinances and codes. By issuing a registration the village has not waived the full
enforcement of any other ordinances nor is the possession of a valid registration a defense of any violation. (Ord. 2007-24, 12-11-2007)
Chapter 2
LIQUOR CONTROL1
3-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively:
ALCOHOL: The product of distillation of any fermented liquid, whether rectified or diluted, whatever may be the origin thereof, and includes synthetic ethyl
alcohol. It does not include denatured alcohol or wood alcohol.
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Includes alcohol, spirits, wine and beer, and every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer, and
capable of being consumed as a beverage by a human being. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to alcohol used in the manufacture of
denatured alcohol produced in accordance with acts of congress and regulations promulgated thereunder, nor to any liquid or solid containing one-half of
one percent (0.5%), or less, of alcohol by volume. No fees provided for in this chapter shall apply to wine intended for use and used by any church or
religious organization for sacramental purposes; provided, that such wine shall be purchased from a licensed manufacturer or importing distributor under
this chapter.
BEER: A beverage obtained by alcoholic fermentation of an infusion or concoction of barley, or other grain, malt, and hops in water, and includes, among
other things, beer, ale, stout, lager beer, porter, and the like.
CLUB: A corporation organized under laws of the state, not for pecuniary profit, solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale or
consumption of alcoholic liquors, kept, used and maintained by its members through the payment of annual dues, and owning, hiring or leasing a building
or space in a building, of such extent and character as may be suitable and adequate for the reasonable and comfortable use and accommodation of its
members and their guests and provided with suitable and adequate kitchen and dining room space and equipment and maintaining a sufficient number of
servants and employees for cooking, preparing and serving food and meals for its members and their guests; provided, that such club files with the local
liquor control commissioner at the time of its application for a license under this chapter two (2) copies of a list of names and residences of its members,
and similarly files within ten (10) days of the election of any additional member his or her name and address; and, provided further, that its affairs and
management are conducted by a board of directors, executive committee, or similar body chosen by the members at their annual meeting, and that no
member or any officer, agent, or employee of the club is paid, or directly or indirectly receives, in the form of salary or other compensation, any profits from
the distribution or sale of alcoholic liquor to the club or the members of the club or its guests introduced by members beyond the amount of such salary as
may be fixed and voted at any annual meeting by the members or by its board of directors or other governing body out of the general revenue of the club.
CONTINUOUS OPERATION: Operation of the licensed business for at least five (5) hours a day for a period of at least five (5) days a week.
DISTRIBUTOR: Any person, firm, business or corporation, other than a manufacturer, who is engaged in the village in purchasing, storing, possessing or
warehousing any alcoholic liquor for resale.
HIS/HER: Any pronoun indicating a particular gender shall be construed to mean either the male or female gender unless the context requires that a
specific gender is intended.
HOTEL: Every building or other structure kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public to be a place where food is actually served and
consumed and sleeping accommodations are offered for adequate pay to travelers and guests, whether transient, permanent or residential, in which
twenty five (25) or more rooms are used for sleeping accommodations of such guests and having one or more public dining rooms where meals are
served to such guests, such sleeping accommodations and dining rooms being conducted in the same building or buildings in connection therewith and
such building or buildings, structure or structures being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity.
ILLINOIS LIQUOR CONTROL ACT: An act passed by the 58th Illinois general assembly entitled "An Act Relating To Alcoholic Liquors", approved January
31, 1934, as amended2.
ILLINOIS LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSION; STATE COMMISSION: The commission created by 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-1.
LICENSED PREMISES: The premises described in the application for the license or in the license as the place where the business to be covered or
covered by the license is to be, or is carried on. This term shall include only the permanent structure housing the licensed business as distinguished from
parking lots and the remainder of the property outside such structure but on the owned or rented property, unless a different definition is logically required.
LICENSEE, APPLICANT: Shall include all persons who are owners or are in control of any place where the sale or distribution of alcoholic liquor is carried
on, whether they be individuals, partners, corporations, joint stock companies, fiduciaries or officers, directors, stockholders or employee, manager or
bartender.
MANAGER: A person employed by a licensee for the purpose of overseeing the operation of a licensed business and exercising discretionary authority on
behalf of the licensee during the hours that the manager is on duty.
MINOR: Any person under twenty one (21) years of age, unless otherwise indicated.
ORIGINAL PACKAGE: A bottle, flask, jug, can, barrel, keg, hogshead or other receptacle or container, whatsoever, used, corked or capped, sealed and
labeled by the manufacturer of an alcoholic liquor, to contain and to convey any alcoholic liquor.
PACKAGE SALES: The sale or offering for sale at retail of alcoholic liquor in the original package, and not to be consumed or in fact consumed in whole or
in part on the premises where sold.
RENTAL HALL BUSINESS: A business organized in such a way that it provides a place available for rental by members of the general public. The building
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 74/338
housing the business must be designed to accommodate a minimum of two hundred fifty (250) persons safely. Such a business is typified by wedding
celebrations, parties or dances by private clubs or individuals. In this type of business, the lessor/licensee is paid a fee by the lessee for the use of the hall
and for providing alcoholic liquor.
RESTAURANT: Any public place having regular menus, which is kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are
served, and where meals are actually and regularly served, such space being provided with adequate and separate sanitary kitchen and dining room
equipment and capacity and having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook, and serve suitable food for its guests.
In addition, any business claiming to be a "restaurant" must document, upon demand, that fifty percent (50%) or more of its gross receipts is derived from
the sale of food as distinguished from alcoholic liquor.
RETAIL ESTABLISHMENT WHERE THE SALE OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR IS NOT THE PRINCIPAL BUSINESS: Any establishment holding a license for
the sale of alcoholic liquor where more than fifty percent (50%) of its gross sales or revenues for any calendar month in the preceding twelve (12) months
are for items or services other than alcoholic liquors.
RETAILER: A person who sells, or offers for sale, alcoholic liquor for use or consumption and not for resale in any form.
SALE: Any transfer, exchange, or barter in any manner, or by any means whatsoever, including the transfer of alcoholic liquors by and through the transfer
or negotiation of warehouse receipts or certificates, and includes and means all sales made by any person, whether principal, proprietor, agent, servant, or
employee. The term "sale" includes any transfer of alcoholic liquor from a foreign importer's license to an importing distributor's license even if both
licenses are held by the same person.
SELL: Includes to solicit or receive an order for, to keep or expose for sale and to keep with intent to sell.
SELL AT RETAIL AND SALE AT RETAIL: Sales for use or consumption and not for resale in any form.
SPIRITS: Any beverage which contains alcohol obtained by distillation, mixed with water or other substance in solution, and includes brandy, rum,
whiskey, gin, or other spirituous liquors, and such liquors when rectified, blended, or otherwise mixed with alcohol or other substances.
WINE: Any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural contents of fruits or vegetables, containing sugar, including such beverages
when fortified by the addition of "alcohol" or "spirits", as defined herein. (Ord. 2000-27, 8-8-2000; amd. 2001 Code; Ord. 2012-10, 3-13-2012)
3-2-2: LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER AND LICENSE COMMITTEE:
A. Liquor Control Commissioner:
1. Mayor Serve As: The mayor of the village shall be the local liquor control commissioner within the corporate limits of the village.
2. Powers:
a. The local liquor control commissioner is charged with the administration, within the village, of the appropriate provisions of state law relating to
alcoholic liquor and the provisions of this chapter as well as any other ordinances and resolutions relating to alcoholic liquors as may be enacted.
b. The local liquor control commissioner shall have the following powers, functions and duties with respect to licenses issued under the provisions of
this chapter:
(1) To grant and/or suspend or revoke for cause all licenses issued to persons for premises within the corporate limits of the village. (Ord. 2000-27,
8-8-2000)
(2) Subject to all requirements of this chapter, to transfer any license to the spouse of a deceased licensee. (Ord. 2000-27, 8-8-2000; amd. 2001
Code)
(3) To enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter at any time upon any premises licensed hereunder to determine whether any
provisions of the Illinois liquor control act or any rules or regulations adopted by the village board, the local liquor control commissioner or by the
state commission are being violated and, at such time, to examine the premises of the licensee in connection therewith.
(4) To receive complaints from any citizen within his jurisdiction that any of the provisions of the Illinois liquor control act, or any rules or regulations
adopted pursuant thereto, or any of the provisions of this chapter have been or are being violated and to act upon such complaints.
(5) To receive fees for licenses issued hereunder and to pay the same forthwith to the village treasurer.
(6) To draw his order on the village treasurer for the payment by the treasurer, out of license fees collected, of all reasonable expenses incurred by
the commissioner for necessary printing, stationery and postage.
(7) To appoint a special investigator to investigate as to compliance with or violation of the provisions of this chapter by a person selling intoxicating
liquor at retail within the jurisdiction of the commissioner. The investigator shall be employed for not more than sixty (60) days in any one license
or calendar year, and shall be paid at a rate to be established by the commissioner. The commissioner shall certify to the village treasurer the
number of days for which the investigator was actually employed, and draw his warrant on the village treasurer for the payment to the
investigator out of the license fees collected the per diem earned by the investigator.
B. License Committee: The village board of trustees will act as a license committee to assist the mayor in the exercise of the powers and the performance
of the duties set out in this chapter and by state law and to make recommendations on issues before him. (Ord. 2000-27, 8-8-2000)
3-2-3: LICENSE AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
No person shall sell, keep or offer for sale at retail, or conduct any place for the sale at retail, of alcoholic liquor within the corporate limits and territory of
the village without having a license to do so issued by the local liquor control commissioner of the village and a valid license for the purpose issued by the
Illinois liquor control commission. A similar valid license issued by the local liquor control commissioner of the village is required for and with respect to
each building location and premises within the village at or upon which alcoholic liquor is to be sold or kept or offered for sale at retail. It shall likewise be
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 75/338
unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any alcoholic liquors, or alcoholic or malt or vinous beverages in violation of the terms and conditions of the
license. (Ord. 2000-27, 8-8-2000)
3-2-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
A. Generally: No adult entertainment business, or business engaging in adult entertainment business activities, is eligible to receive or maintain the license
required by this chapter. All applications for the license required by this chapter shall be made in writing to the mayor, or to the persons designated by
him, signed by the applicant if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof if a club or corporation, verified by oath or affidavit, and shall contain
the following information and statements: (Ord. 2012-10, 3-13-2012)
1. The type of license being applied for.
2. The name, address and date of birth of the applicant in the case of an individual; in the case a copartnership, the persons entitled to share in the
profits thereof; and in the case of a corporation for profit or a club, the date of incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, and the names
and addresses of the officers, directors, and the registered agent.
3. The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth, and if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization.
4. The character of business of the applicant, and in case of a corporation, the objects for which it was formed.
5. The length of time that the applicant has been in business of that character, and in case of a corporation, the date on which its charter was issued.
6. The location and description of the premises or place of business which is to be operated under such license.
7. A statement whether applicant has made similar applications for similar license or premises other than described in the application and the
disposition of such application.
8. A statement that applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing
contained in this chapter, the laws of the state or the ordinances of the village.
9. Whether a previous license by any state, or subdivision thereof, or by the federal government has been revoked, and if so, the reasons therefor.
10. A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the state or of the United States or any ordinance of the village.
11. If the applicant is a partnership or corporation or if the place of business that is to be operated under such license will not be managed by the
named applicant, then the application shall show thereon the name and address of the person who will manage said place of business.
12. Proof of ownership of the premises or copy of lease or purchase agreement authorizing applicant to occupy and conduct business in said premises
(lease must be for duration of license).
13. List of addresses of all locations applicant has ever engaged in the business of sales of alcoholic liquor at retail.
14. Illinois business tax number.
15. List of dram shop insurance coverage, including name and address of insurance company for both the licensee and owner of the building in which
alcoholic liquor will be sold for the duration of the license, and a copy of the certificate of liquor liability insurance.
16. Such other information as the local liquor control commissioner shall deem appropriate or necessary.
B. Partnerships And Corporations: In case of a partnership or corporation, the information and statements required by this section shall be furnished as to
each partner, as to the president and secretary of the corporation, as well as to the location of the principal office of the corporation. (Ord. 2000-27, 8-8-
2000)
3-2-5: DENIAL OF LICENSE TO CERTAIN PERSONS AUTHORIZED:
A license may be denied by the local liquor control commissioner if:
A. An applicant is not a resident of Madison County and fails to designate a Madison County resident for purpose of service of process or other notice.
B. A person is not of good character and reputation in the community in which he resides, or has most recently resided.
C. A person is not a citizen of the United States, unless the person is a joint licensee with a person who is a citizen.
D. A person has been convicted of a felony under any federal or state law.
E. A person has been convicted of pandering or other crimes and misdemeanors opposed to decency or morality or dishonesty.
F. A person's liquor license has been revoked.
G. A person, at the time of application for renewal of any license issued hereunder, would not be eligible for the license upon a first application.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 76/338
H. A partnership, unless all of the members of the partnership are qualified to obtain a license.
I. A corporation, if any officer, manager, or director would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence
within Madison County.
J. A corporation, unless it is incorporated in Illinois, or unless it is a foreign corporation which is qualified under the Illinois business corporation act3 to
transact business in Illinois.
K. A person's place of business is conducted by a manager or agent, unless the manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the
licensee, and a corporation or association or partnership must have a manager or agent so qualified.
L. A person has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor subsequent to
January 31, 1934, or shall have forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any violation.
M. A person does not own the premises for which a license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the license is to be
issued, and if a lease, the lease shall be recorded in the office of the county recorder.
N. A person is any law enforcing public official, any mayor, alderman, or member of a city council or commission, any president of a village board of
trustees, any member of a village board of trustees or the chairman or any member of a county board; and no official shall be interested in any way,
either directly or indirectly, in the manufacture, sale, or distribution of alcoholic liquor; except, that a license may be granted to such official in relation to
premises which are not located within the jurisdiction of that official if the issuance of such license is approved by the state liquor control commission.
O. A person is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated by the license.
P. A person has been convicted of a gambling offense as prescribed by one of the divisions of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/28-1 et seq.
Q. Any premises has not been inspected and approved as complying with the laws of the village as to the zoning requirements, construction, and
sanitation facilities.
R. Any person, association or corporation is not eligible for a state retail liquor dealer's license. (Ord. 2000-27, 8-8-2000)
3-2-6: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
All persons or corporations issued a liquor license hereunder shall provide evidence of dram shop insurance in an amount approved by the local liquor
control commissioner. Said insurance shall be evidenced by a certificate of insurance acceptable to the local liquor control commissioner and delivered
prior to opening of the establishment. (Ord. 2000-27, 8-8-2000)
3-2-7: INVESTIGATIONS AND EXAMINATIONS; ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
A. Investigation Of Applicant; Issuance Of License: The local liquor control commissioner shall investigate all applications for a local retail liquor license
and may examine each applicant as to his qualifications therefor and shall thereafter grant or deny a retail liquor license for each applicant. The local
liquor control commissioner is authorized to grant and issue and revoke licenses to sell at retail, and to keep and offer for sale at retail, alcoholic liquors
within the corporate limits and territory of the village upon the conditions and in the manner provided by this chapter and state law relating to alcoholic
liquor, and not otherwise. The license shall be in writing and shall be signed by the local liquor control commissioner.
B. Examination Of Applicants And Licensees: The local liquor control commissioner shall have a right to examine or cause to be examined, under oath,
any applicant for a license or for the renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of revocation has been served in the manner provided by law,
and to examine, or cause to be examined, the books and records of any applicant or licensee; to hear testimony and take proofs for his information in
the performance of his duties and for this purpose to issue subpoenas, as provided by law. For the purpose of obtaining any information desired by the
local liquor control commissioner under this subsection, he may authorize his agent or investigator to act on his behalf. (Ord. 2000-27, 8-8-2000)
3-2-8: TERMINATION OF LICENSE:
The license shall expire on July 1. (Ord. 2000-27, 8-8-2000)
3-2-9: CLASSIFICATION OF LICENSES; FEES; RESTRICTIONS ON CERTAIN LICENSES:
A. Classifications And Fees: Licenses to sell alcoholic liquor at retail shall fall into one of the following classes: (Ord. 2015-3, 1-27-2015)
1. Class A: A class A license shall entitle the licensee to sell alcoholic liquor, at retail, for consumption either: a) on the premises; or b) off of the
premises where sold in the original package. The annual fee for such license shall be six hundred twenty five dollars ($625.00).
2. Class B: A class B license shall entitle the licensee to sell alcoholic liquor, in the original package only for consumption off of the premises, but shall
not authorize consumption on the premises. The annual fee for such license shall be six hundred twenty five dollars ($625.00). (Ord. 2010-14, 5-25-
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 77/338
2010)
3. Class C: A class C license shall entitle the licensee to sell alcoholic liquor, at retail for consumption on the premises by the general public or a private
party, in conjunction with hall or room rentals where a charge is made there directly or indirectly through an admission fee, service charge, meal
charge, donation or any other charge whatsoever. A class C license can only be issued to a licensee that already holds a class A, D, E or F license.
The annual fee for such license shall be six hundred twenty five dollars ($625.00). (Ord. 2015-3, 1-27-2015)
4. Class D: A class D license shall entitle the licensee to sell alcoholic liquor as part of a restaurant business, for consumption on the premises only.
The annual fee for such license shall be six hundred twenty five dollars ($625.00).
5. Class E: A class E license shall entitle the licensee to sell beer and wine only, as part of a restaurant business, for consumption on the premises
only. The annual fee for such license shall be four hundred seventy five dollars ($475.00).
6. Class F: A class F license shall entitle the licensee to sell alcoholic liquor at retail for consumption on the premises, or off the premises where sold in
the original package, by "clubs" to members and/or their guests as the same are herein defined. The annual fee for such license shall be one
hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). Under no circumstances, shall a class F license be issued to persons, firms, or corporations operating a for profit
activity where alcoholic liquor is served either to the public or persons attending a private party where a charge is made therefor either directly or
indirectly through an admission fee, service charge, meal charge, donation, room rental or any other charge whatsoever.
7. Class G: A class G license shall entitle the licensee to sell alcoholic liquor, at retail for consumption on the premises by the general public or a
