impose a minimum fine as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code.
B. In determining intent under subsection A of this section, the proximity of the cannabis drug paraphernalia or the presence of cannabis on the drug
paraphernalia may be considered. (Ord. 2018-18, 6-12-2018)
5-7-4: EXEMPT ITEMS; DETERMINATION:
A. Exempt Items:
1. Items marketed for the use in the preparation, compounding, packaging, labeling, or other use of cannabis as an incident to lawful research,
teaching, or chemical analysis and not for sale; or
2. Items marketed for, or historically and customarily used in connection with the planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing,
compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting,
ingesting, or inhaling of tobacco or any other lawful substance.
3. Items exempt under this subsection include, but are not limited to, garden hoes, rakes, sickles, baggies, tobacco pipes, and cigarette-rolling papers.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 132/338
4. Items listed in subsection A3 of this section which are marketed for decorative purposes, when such items have been rendered completely
inoperable or incapable of being used for any illicit purpose prohibited by this section.
B. Considerations: In determining whether or not a particular item is exempt under this section, all other logically relevant factors should be considered,
including the following:
1. The general, usual, customary, and historical use to which the item involved has been put;
2. Expert evidence concerning the ordinary or customary use of the item and the effect of any peculiarity in the design or engineering of the item upon
its functioning;
3. Any written instructions accompanying the delivery of the item concerning the purposes or uses to which the item can or may be put;
4. Any oral instructions provided by the seller of the item at the time and place of sale or commercial delivery;
5. Any national or local advertising, concerning the design, purpose or use of the item involved, and the entire context in which such advertising occurs;
6. The manner, place and circumstances in which the item was displayed for sale, as well as any item or items displayed for sale or otherwise exhibited
upon the premises where the sale was made;
7. Whether the owner or anyone in control of the object is a legitimate supplier of like or related items to the community, such as a licensed distributor
or dealer of tobacco products;
8. The existence and scope of legitimate uses for the object in the community. (Ord. 2018-18, 6-12-2018)
5-7-5: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this section relating to the possession of cannabis shall be applicable to the possession of any quantity of cannabis less than thirty
grams (30 g). (Ord. 2018-18, 6-12-2018)
5-7-6: PENALTIES; VIOLATIONS:
Any person or entity violating this chapter shall be guilty of an ordinance violation. (Ord. 2018-18, 6-12-2018)
Title 6
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
Chapter 1
VEHICLE LICENSES
(Rep. by Ord. 2003-25, 6-24-2003)
Chapter 2
GENERAL TRAFFIC PROVISIONS
6-2-1: SHORT TITLE:
This title may be known as and cited as the GLEN CARBON TRAFFIC ORDINANCE. (Ord. 469, 1-2-1972)
6-2-2: INTERPRETATION AND SCOPE:
A. Interpretation: This title shall be so interpreted and construed as to effectuate its general purpose to make uniform the laws of those local authorities
which enact it.
B. Scope: This title shall not have a retroactive effect and shall not apply to any traffic accident, or any cause of action arising out of a traffic accident, or
judgment arising therefrom, or to any violation of this title occurring prior to the effective date hereof. (Ord. 469, 1-2-1972)
6-2-3: ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED:
Except insofar as the application thereof is clearly impractical or inappropriate, in view of the context of purposes or penalty as provided, all of the
definitions, requirements, regulations, prohibitions, provisions and sections of the Illinois vehicle code1, as amended, are hereby adopted by the village.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 133/338
Any and all violations thereof shall be considered violations of this title, and each such violation shall subject the violator thereof to penalty provisions
under section 1-4-1 of this code if proceeded hereunder. (2001 Code)
6-2-4: TRAFFIC REGULATIONS ON SPECIFIC STREETS:
Designated activities on specific streets in the village, i.e., stop, yield, parking, one-way travel, vehicle loads, shall be listed and on file in the office of the
village clerk for public use and inspection. (2001 Code)
6-2-5: GENERAL, EMERGENCY AND EXPERIMENTAL TRAFFIC REGULATIONS:
The chief of police is hereby empowered to make regulations necessary to make and enforce temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies
or special conditions. No such temporary or experimental regulation shall remain in effect for more than ninety (90) days. (Ord. 469, 1-2-1972; amd. 2001
Code)
6-2-6: TOWING:
The Glen Carbon police department will keep and utilize a towing list for occasions when the vehicle owner does not have a preference of towing
companies, and select a towing company from that list on a rotating basis. The list will be comprised of those automobile towing businesses located within
the corporate limits of the village of Glen Carbon. (Ord. 2002-59, 11-26-2002)
Chapter 3
SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES
6-3-1: AUTHORITY TO IMPOUND VEHICLES:
A. Members of the village of Glen Carbon police department are hereby authorized to remove or cause to be removed, any motor vehicle from a street or
highway to a place of safety or to a motor vehicle storage facility approved by the village of Glen Carbon or otherwise maintained by the village of Glen
Carbon under the circumstances hereinafter enumerated and to impound such motor vehicle until all fees and charges as provided in this chapter have
been paid, satisfied or challenged as provided for by this chapter.
1. When any motor vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, viaduct, railroad track or right of way, or causeway, or in any tunnel where such motor
vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic.
2. When a motor vehicle upon a highway is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the person or persons in charge of the motor
vehicle are by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its removal or designate a responsible licensed
driver to assume custody of the motor vehicle and cause its safe removal.
3. When any motor vehicle is left unattended upon a street and is so parked illegally as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal
movement of traffic, or an obstruction to any private driveway.
4. When any abandoned motor vehicle is found on any street or highway, a vehicle shall be deemed abandoned when: a) in such state of disrepair as
to be incapable of being driven, or b) not used or moved for more than five (5) consecutive days and is apparently deserted, or c) is left unattended
and becomes by reason of fire, snow or any happening or occurrence, a hazard to public safety and convenience.
5. Whenever a motor vehicle is left parked and unattended on a street or on any other properly designated public facility, which street or other facility
has been designated by village ordinance as an area in which parking is prohibited, and which no parking prohibition is properly posted including
designation as a "towing zone", the members of the police department are hereby authorized to cause such motor vehicle to be removed from said
street or other public facility by a towing service and impounded.
6. When any motor vehicle, operated with the express or implied permission of the owner or owners of record, is used in connection with the following
violations, it shall be subject to seizure, removal and impoundment by order of a member of the police department of the village of Glen Carbon, and
the owner or owners of record of said motor vehicle shall thereafter be liable to the village of Glen Carbon for a level 1 administrative fee, as provided
for in this chapter, together with any towing and storage fees incurred, as provided by this chapter.
a. Possession or delivery of a controlled substance or drug paraphernalia as defined by the controlled substances act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes
570/201 et seq., the cannabis control act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., or the drug paraphernalia act of the state of Illinois, 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 600/2 so long as the offense charged is a class A misdemeanor or is a more serious offense as defined by the Illinois
criminal code.
b. Any weapons offense as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24.
c. Driving under the influence (DUI) of alcohol, drugs or intoxicating compounds as defined by the state of Illinois in section 5/11-501 of the Illinois
vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-501.
d. The offense of the commission of prostitution as defined in section 5/11-14 of the criminal code, solicitation of a sexual act as defined in section
5/11-14.1 of such code, soliciting for a prostitute as defined in section 5/11-15 of such code, soliciting for a juvenile prostitute as defined in section
5/11-18 of such code, patronizing a juvenile prostitute as defined in section 5/11-18.1 of such code, or pandering as defined in section 5/11-16 of
such code of a prostitute as defined by the criminal code of the state of Illinois.
e. Driving with suspended or revoked driver's license as defined in section 5/6-303 of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-303
except and unless the driver's license was suspended solely as a result of violation of vehicle emission regulations as required by 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/13C-55(a)(2).
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 134/338
f. Fleeing or attempting to elude a police officer as defined in section 5/11-204 or 11-204.1 of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/11-204 and 204.1.
g. Leaving the scene of a personal injury or property damage accident as defined in sections 5/11-401, 5/11-402 and 5/11-403 of the Illinois vehicle
code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-401, 402 and 403.
h. Violation of any outstanding order of protection as defined in 750 Illinois Compiled Statutes 30/2-12 or domestic battery offense as defined in 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-3.2.
i. Any and all arrests for felony offenses as defined by the state of Illinois criminal code or by the criminal code of the United States Of America.
7. When any motor vehicle, operated with the express or implied permission of the owner or owners of record, is used in connection with the following
violations, it shall be subject to seizure, removal and impoundment by order of a member of the police department of the village of Glen Carbon, and
the owner or owners of record of said motor vehicle shall be liable to the village of Glen Carbon for a level 2 administrative fee, as provided for in this
chapter, together with any towing and storage fees incurred, as provided by this chapter.
a. Any custodial arrest of a suspect for a misdemeanor as defined by the Illinois criminal code and not included in those offenses enumerated in
subsection A6 of this section.
b. Any custodial arrest of a suspect for a traffic violation as defined by the Illinois vehicle code or by this code and not included in those offenses
enumerated in subsection A6 of this section.
c. Any custodial arrest of a suspect on an outstanding misdemeanor warrant for arrest issued by any court of competent jurisdiction and not included
in those offenses enumerated in subsection A6 of this section.
8. When any motor vehicle, operated with the express or implied permission of the owner or owners of record is subject to removal, seizure or
impoundment by order of a member of the police department of the village of Glen Carbon for any reason not enumerated in subsection A6 or A7 of
this section, the owner or owners of record of said motor vehicle shall be liable to the village for a level 3 administrative fee, as provided for in this
chapter, together with any towing and storage fees incurred, as provided in this chapter.
B. Whenever a member of the police department of the village of Glen Carbon causes a motor vehicle to be removed, towed or impounded as authorized
by this code, the police department of the village of Glen Carbon shall use due diligence to ascertain the name and address of the owner or owners of
record thereof and shall give or cause to be given notice in writing to such owner or owners of record of the fact of such removal, towing and
impoundment and the reasons therefor and of the place to which such motor vehicle had been removed, towed or impounded.
C. Whenever a member of the police department of the village of Glen Carbon causes a motor vehicle to be removed, towed or impounded as authorized
by this section, and the police department of the village of Glen Carbon is unable after due diligence to ascertain the name and address of the owner or
owners of record, or for any other reason is unable to give the written notice to the owner or owners of record as provided herein, and in the event the
motor vehicle is not returned to the owner within a period of three (3) business days following its removal, towing or impoundment, then, and in that
event, the police department of the village of Glen Carbon shall send or cause to be sent a written report of such removal, towing or impoundment by
mail to the secretary of state of the state of Illinois. Such notice shall include a complete description of the vehicle, the date, time and place from which
the motor vehicle was removed, the reasons for such removal and the name of the towing agent and place where the motor vehicle is impounded.
D. A member of the police department of the village of Glen Carbon who shall be authorized by this code to cause a motor vehicle to be seized, removed,
towed and/or impounded shall not be required to exercise that authority. A member of the police department may, in his or her discretion, permit an
owner or an authorized agent of an owner, to assume custody and control of the motor vehicle if a licensed driver under circumstances determined in
the judgment of the member of the police department to be reasonably safe and appropriate. (Ord. 2017-8, 3-14-2017)
6-3-2: IMPOUNDMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES:
A. Definitions: The following terms shall be defined as hereinafter set forth for the purpose of this chapter:
BUSINESS DAY: Any day in which the offices of village hall are open to the public for a minimum of seven (7) hours.
LEVEL 1 ADMINISTRATIVE FEE: Fifty dollars ($50.00).
LEVEL 2 ADMINISTRATIVE FEE: Twenty five dollars ($25.00).
LEVEL 3 ADMINISTRATIVE FEE: Zero dollars ($0.00).
MOTOR VEHICLE: Every vehicle which is self-propelled, including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, vans, motorcycles and motor scooters.
OWNER OF RECORD: The record title holder or holders of a motor vehicle as registered with the secretary of state of the state of Illinois, or if not
registered in Illinois, the particular state in which the motor vehicle is registered. If the motor vehicle is not required by law to be registered, the owner of
record shall be the legal owner as determined by law following reasonable due diligence to determine the owner by authorities of the village of Glen
Carbon.
B. Documentation: Before the owner of record or person entitled to possession of any impounded motor vehicle shall be permitted to remove the same, he
or she shall furnish documentation of the following:
1. His or her true identity.
2. Ownership of the motor vehicle.
3. His or her right of possession of the motor vehicle.
4. Proof of registration of licensing of the motor vehicle with the appropriate state authorities.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 135/338
5. Proof of insurance for the operation of the motor vehicle in accordance with the laws of the state of Illinois.
6. Proof of a valid driver's license held by the person who shall drive the motor vehicle from the impoundment area.
C. Administrative Fee: Before the owner of record or other person is entitled to possession of any motor vehicle impounded by authority of the police
department of the village of Glen Carbon, an administrative fee shall be paid to the village of Glen Carbon. The administrative fee shall be a "level 1
administrative fee", a "level 2 administrative fee" or a "level 3 administrative fee" as defined by this section and by section 10 of this chapter. The
appropriate fee shall be paid at the village of Glen Carbon police department prior to the release of the motor vehicle as partial reimbursement to the
village of Glen Carbon police department in compensation for the time and resources spent by the department regarding the seizure, impoundment and
release of said motor vehicles. The appropriate fee shall also be imposed and paid as a penalty to the owner of the vehicle as a deterrent to the owner
permitting a driver to utilize the owner's vehicle in such a manner as to require a removal and impoundment of a vehicle under the circumstances
described in this chapter so as to give rise to an administrative fee. The appropriate fees are to be paid by the registered owner or other authorized
person seeking the vehicle's release, regardless of whether the registered owner of said motor vehicle or any other authorized person was driving the
motor vehicle prior to the circumstances which gave rise to the impoundment of the motor vehicle by the village of Glen Carbon police department.
D. Release Of Impounded Vehicle: It shall be the duty of the towing or storage company in possession of the impounded motor vehicle to obtain
documentation issued by the village of Glen Carbon police department confirming compliance with the foregoing requirements prior to releasing the
motor vehicle and to retain photocopies of that documentation in their files for a period of not less than six (6) months following the release of each
respective motor vehicle. The foregoing information shall be made available by the towing or storage company to the authorities of the village of Glen
Carbon police department for inspection and copying upon request. The towing or storage company is prohibited from releasing any motor vehicle they
may tow pursuant to the direction of the village of Glen Carbon police department until and unless the towing or storage company obtains the
documentation as aforesaid.
E. Release Fee: The towing or storage company shall be entitled to receive a fee from the owner or person entitled to possession of any such motor
vehicle prior to the release of the motor vehicle. The fee shall be to cover the cost of removing said motor vehicle and, in addition thereto, the cost of
storage of said motor vehicle for each day or fraction thereof that said motor vehicle shall have remained stored.
F. Fees In Addition To Violation Fees: The foregoing fees shall be in addition to any fees levied or assessed against the owner or operator of said motor
vehicle by reason of violation of any ordinance, statute or warrant which may have resulted from such violation that may have been the basis of or
associated with the impoundment of the motor vehicle.
G. Notification: Whenever a police officer of the village of Glen Carbon has reason to believe that a motor vehicle is subject to seizure, removal and
impoundment pursuant to this code, the state of Illinois or federal law, the police officer shall provide for the removal of the motor vehicle to a facility
approved by the village of Glen Carbon. At the time of the seizure, removal and impoundment of a motor vehicle, the police officer shall attempt to
notify any person identifying himself or herself as the owner of the respective motor vehicle or the person who is found to be in control of the motor
vehicle at that time, if present, of the fact of the seizure of the motor vehicle and of the right of the owner of the motor vehicle to request an
administrative hearing in accordance with the provisions of this section.
H. Administrative Hearing: At the time a motor vehicle is seized, removed or impounded or within five (5) business days after a motor vehicle is seized,
removed and impounded by order or direction of a police officer of the village of Glen Carbon, the village of Glen Carbon shall notify by personal
service or by certified mail the owner or owners of record of the owner's right to request an administrative hearing to challenge whether violation of this
chapter has occurred or to contest the administrative fee imposed in connection with the seizure or impoundment of the motor vehicle. The owner of
record or his or her attorney seeking a hearing must file a written request for a hearing with the office of the chief of police of the village of Glen Carbon
no later than ten (10) business days after the aforesaid notice was mailed or personally served, whichever first occurred. Upon the request of a
hearing, in writing filed with the office of the chief of police of the village of Glen Carbon within the aforesaid time allowed, a hearing date must be
scheduled no more than twenty (20) business days thereafter. The person seeking a hearing shall have the burden of proof establishing that a request
for an administrative hearing was timely filed with the office of the chief of police. Any interested person shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be
heard at the hearing. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the hearing and hearsay evidence shall be admissible. The hearing may be
continued once commenced to a subsequent time and date certain. The chief of police shall serve as a hearing officer, or he may designate another
individual to serve as a hearing officer on a case by case basis. No person involved in the particular seizure, removal or impoundment decision or
process may serve as a hearing officer.
If, after the hearing, the hearing officer determines by a preponderance of the evidence presented that the motor vehicle was properly subject to
seizure, removal and impoundment by order of a member of the village of Glen Carbon police department, then the hearing officer shall enter a written
order finding the owner or owners of record of the respective motor vehicle civilly liable to the village of Glen Carbon for the applicable administrative
fee as provided by this chapter.
If, after a hearing, the hearing officer does not determine by a preponderance of the evidence that the motor vehicle was properly subject to seizure
and impoundment by order of a member of the village of Glen Carbon police department, then the hearing officer shall enter a written finding for the
record owner and grant such relief as may be appropriate, including waiver of all or a portion of the administrative fee and the return of the motor
vehicle to the record owner.
If the owner or owners of record request a hearing but fail to appear at the hearing, or if the owner or owners of record fail to request a hearing in
writing in a timely manner, the owner or owners of record shall be deemed to have waived his or her rights to an administrative hearing and the hearing
officer may enter a default order in favor of the village of Glen Carbon in the amount of the appropriate administrative fee.
The owner or owners of record may elect to pay the administrative fee deemed necessary to redeem the motor vehicle without constituting a waiver of
the right of the owner or owners of record to request an administrative hearing in writing and in a timely manner as provided by this chapter and upon
payment of the appropriate administrative fee, together with any towing and storage fees incurred, the motor vehicle shall be returned to the owner or
owners of record without further bond. The action of the Glen Carbon police department shall be subject to administrative review as provided herein.
The final written decision of the village of Glen Carbon police chief or his designated hearing officer shall constitute a final administrative order and be
subject to judicial review under the provisions of the administrative review act of the state of Illinois.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 136/338
I. Disposition Of Impounded Vehicles: An administrative fee imposed pursuant to this chapter shall constitute a debt due and owing the village of Glen
Carbon. A motor vehicle impounded pursuant to this chapter shall remain impounded until:
1. The administrative fee is paid in full to the village of Glen Carbon and all applicable towing and storage fees are paid to the towing agent and all of
the requirements of subsection B of this section have been satisfied; or
2. The motor vehicle is deemed abandoned, in which case the motor vehicle shall be disposed of in the manner provided by law for the disposition of
abandoned motor vehicles; and
3. Any motor vehicle that is not properly redeemed by the record owner or owners within thirty (30) days after the expiration of the appropriate time
during which the owner or owners of record may seek a further administrative or judicial review of the village's actions in causing a motor vehicle to
be seized, towed and impounded under this chapter, may be disposed of as an unclaimed motor vehicle as provided by law; provided, however, that
where proceedings have been instituted under state or federal drug asset forfeiture laws, the subject motor vehicle may not be disposed of by the
village of Glen Carbon except as consistent with those proceedings. (Ord. 2017-8, 3-14-2017)
6-3-3: SALE OF UNCLAIMED MOTOR VEHICLES:
Whenever any motor vehicle so impounded as aforesaid shall remain unclaimed by the owner or other person legally entitled to possession thereof for a
period of thirty (30) days from and after notice shall have been given, the police department shall sell such motor vehicle at public auction to the highest
bidder for cash, the time and place of such sale to be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the village, not less than ten (10) nor
more than fifteen (15) days before the date of such sale. The police department shall cause a notice of such sale to be mailed to the secretary of state,
said notice to contain a full description of every motor vehicle to be sold and the time and place of sale, provided any such motor vehicle not sold at the
first sale may be offered for sale and sold at subsequent dates without further notice. The proceeds of such sale after paying all liens and deducting all
reasonable charges and expenses, including the fees and charges herein provided and the expenses of advertising and conducting the sale, shall be paid
to the village treasurer.
No member of the police department, nor any other employee of the village, directly or indirectly, shall purchase or participate in the bidding for or the
purchase of any vehicle offered for sale as aforesaid. (Ord. 2017-8, 3-14-2017)
Title 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
Chapter 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS1
7-1-1: SNOW ROUTES:
A. Routes Designated; Parking Prohibitions: It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any vehicle to park said vehicle on any street or parts of
streets hereinafter designated for a period of time that average accumulations of snow and ice on the ground exceed two inches (2") in depth: (Ord. 78-
28, 1-2-1979)
Birger Street
Cottonwood Road
Cougar Road (Center Grove to Junction Drive)
Glen Crossing Road
Junction Drive (Cougar Road to Illinois Route 159)
Main Street (south side)
Meridian Road
Old Troy Road (village limits)
(Ord. 78-28, 1-2-1979; amd. Ord. 79-11, 9-18-1979; 2001 Code)
B. Parking On Private Property Adjacent To Snow Routes: It shall be unlawful, without the consent of the owner of the property, to park any motor vehicle
on any private property adjacent to the streets described in subsection A of this section and at any time parking is prohibited thereon pursuant to the
terms of this section. (Ord. 78-28, 1-2-1979)
C. Signs Posted: The public works director or other person authorized by the president and board of trustees shall cause signs to be posted in all areas
where parking is prohibited under the terms of this section, indicating such limitations or prohibitions; said signs to bear the words "SNOW ROUTE".
D. Enforcement: The police department, and all members thereof assigned to traffic "snow route" duty, are hereby authorized to remove and tow away, or
have removed and towed away by any commercial towing service, any vehicles illegally parked in any street designated in subsection A of this section
at any time the terms of this section shall be applicable. Vehicles so towed away for illegal parking shall be stored in a safe place and shall be restored
to the owner or operator of such vehicle upon payment of any reasonable fees charged by the towing service. (Ord. 78-28, 1-2-1979; amd. 2001 Code)
7-1-2: RESTRICTIONS ON SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL:
A. Disposal On Streets Prohibited: No person shall dispose of snow or ice from private property by transferring such snow or ice to any street or parts of
streets in the village.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 137/338
B. Handicapped Parking Spaces: No person, firm, corporation or partnership or the owner, tenant, lessee or occupant of any premises having parking
spaces reserved for handicapped drivers or any contractor employed for the removal of snow or ice shall block access to parking spaces reserved for
handicapped drivers by the plowing, piling or placement of snow and ice in such reserved spaces. (Ord. 2014-5, 2-11-2014)
7-1-3: EXCAVATIONS:
A. Permit Required: No person shall make any excavation in or tunnel under any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public place in the village without
having first secured a permit therefor.
B. Application For Permit: Applications for such permits shall be made to the village clerk and shall specify the intended location and the purpose of the
excavation.
C. Bond: No permit shall be issued until the applicant has given the village a bond with adequate surety, indemnifying the village for all liability arising out
of said excavation or tunneling.
D. Safety Precautions: All excavations shall be adequately guarded with approved traffic control devices so as to protect the public from hazard.
E. Restoration Of Excavated Area: Any person making any excavation shall cause the street, alley, sidewalk or other public way to be replaced in a
satisfactory condition within a reasonable time after the completion of the excavation. (2001 Code)
7-1-4: OBSTRUCTING PUBLIC WAYS:
Whoever shall place, or cause to be placed upon any sidewalk, street or alley in the village any goods, wares or merchandise or any other article for sale
or show, or for any other purpose whereby the sidewalk, street or alley may become obstructed, and allow the same to remain after having been notified
by any village officer, and shall not remove such obstruction in a reasonable time, shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each
offense. (1941 Code § 6-1; amd. 2001 Code)
7-1-5: SOLICITATION OF FUNDS ON PUBLIC WAYS:
A. No person shall stand on a highway, road, street or any public way for the purpose of soliciting contributions unless prior approval has been granted by
the village board of trustees; (Ord. 2001-30, 9-25-2001)
B. Solicitation of funds on public ways will be limited to one approved organization on any day and will follow the restrictions set forth by the village. Local
organizations should be given priority and preferential consideration in receiving approval to solicit funds, however, it is recognized that approval to
solicit funds upon a public way within the corporate limits of the village of Glen Carbon is solely at the discretion of the village board; (Ord. 2005-15, 9-
27-2005)
C. In order to obtain approval to solicit contributions, a request must be submitted in writing on a form prepared by the village, and such request must be
submitted in sufficient time to be reviewed by the police department and for the request to go before the village board. Said written application will
include: (Ord. 2001-30, 9-25-2001)
1. The identity of the organization and members who will participate. The organization should be a recognized legitimate charity registered with the
state of Illinois; or a recognized civic service organization that will use the solicited funds for the public benefit and welfare; (Ord. 2005-15, 9-27-
2005)
2. The organization must show proof that it has sufficient insurance coverage and a statement that it is liable for any injuries to any person or property
that may result from their activities and holds the village harmless;
3. The time and location requested to conduct such activity; (Ord. 2001-30, 9-25-2001)
D. Only one charitable organization will be granted authority to solicit contributions on any given date. One factor in determining priority of requests will be
whether the organization has solicited contributions previously during the past twelve (12) months. The board preference is that an organization be
permitted one solicitation a year; (Ord. 2001-30, 9-25-2001; amd. Ord. 2005-15, 9-27-2005)
E. All charitable organizations soliciting contributions will be required to conduct their activities:
1. Only during daylight hours at times designated by the village board;
2. Only at intersections where all traffic is required to come to a complete full stop and designated by the village board;
3. Using proper safety equipment such as orange vests and orange cones as designated by the village;
4. Using adequate supervision of solicitors. All solicitors will be sixteen (16) years of age or older;
F. No solicitation of contributions shall cause any traffic hazard or conduct any type of harassment or hazardous activity, or cause any breach of the peace.
Furthermore, such solicitations shall terminate immediately if so ordered by the Glen Carbon police department. (Ord. 2001-30, 9-25-2001)

Chapter 2
PARKS AND PUBLIC LANDS
7-2-1: OBEDIENCE TO SIGNS AND SIGNALS:
All persons shall obey the instructions of all official signs, markings and traffic signals located within any park or public land, unless otherwise directed by a
police officer or his designated official. (Ord. 98-16, 3-24-1998)
7-2-2: GENERAL USE REGULATIONS:
A. Hours: Except for parking areas where other times have been specifically designated, village parks shall be open to the public beginning at dawn and
closing at sunset each day, except when sanctioned activities are scheduled. No person or group of persons shall be permitted to use such parks or its
facilities outside the limits of the foregoing hours without having first secured a written permit from the village administrator. (Ord. 2013-21, 7-23-2013)
B. Trash And Refuse: Refuse containers of all kinds are provided at the parks, and all users of a park and its facilities shall deposit their trash and refuse in
such containers. It shall be unlawful for any person using a park or its facilities to allow trash or other refuse to be thrown, scattered or otherwise
deposited upon the park premises in other than a container designated for such use.
C. Vehicle And Traffic Control:
1. Vehicles shall be parked only in areas designated for parking or along roadways so long as the vehicles do not block any roadway or driveway.
2. No motorized vehicle shall be operated off the roadways within the confines of any park or public lands unless it is a village maintenance vehicle or
the owner has permission from the public works director to load/unload certain items for large group outings.
3. Vehicles are not permitted on grassy areas or near pavilions or picnic tables.
4. It shall be unlawful to change oil, repair, tune up, or replace any parts on any vehicle in any park or public lands. (Ord. 98-16, 3-24-1998)
D. Liquor: It shall be unlawful to have any alcoholic beverage on park or public lands premises without written permission of the local liquor control
commissioner. (Ord. 98-16, 3-24-1998; amd. 2001 Code)
E. Reservations For Use: Any person wishing to reserve a sheltered pavilion, gazebo, bandstand or log cabin facility must first apply at the office of the
village clerk by written application and receive permission for said use. If the applicant is not a village resident a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) will be
charged. (Ord. 2012-18, 5-22-2012)
F. Restrictions On Certain Activities: Activities such as rollerblading, skateboarding or related activity is strictly prohibited on designated surfaces such as
tennis courts, basketball courts, or under structures such as pavilions, bandstands, gazebos, or log cabin structures. Rollerblading and skateboarding
are prohibited in Schon Park. (Ord. 2013-21, 7-23-2013)
G. Animal Control:
1. It shall be unlawful to permit any animal, pet or reptile to run at large in any park or public lands.
2. No person shall ride any horse, pony or other equestrian animal within the confines of the parks or public lands.
H. Noise Control:
1. It shall be unlawful to cause, create, or make any loud noises in any park or public lands.
2. No amplifying equipment may be used in any park or public lands without written permission of the public works director.
3. It is strictly prohibited to use radios, DVD, CD, or cassette players, televisions or amplification systems in or out of vehicles, or operate vehicles with
modified mufflers which produce loud sounds within any park or public lands. (Ord. 98-16, 3-24-1998)
I. Overnight Activities: Persons are not permitted to remain overnight in any park or public lands unless permission is first obtained from the village
administrator. (Ord. 2013-21, 7-23-2013)
J. Damage To Property:
1. It shall be unlawful to wilfully mark upon, deface, damage, destroy or remove any park facility or property of any nature.
2. It shall be unlawful to climb on any roof structure or get on top of any park building, pavilion, bandstand, comfort stations, gazebo, or log cabin
structures. (Ord. 98-16, 3-24-1998)
K. Firearms Prohibited: No firearms are allowed as delineated by Illinois state statute.
L. Lakes And Waterways:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=599 139/338
1. No swimming, wading or ice skating or ice fishing allowed on lakes or waterways.
2. No boating, of any type, is allowed on lakes or waterways.
3. A valid state of Illinois fishing license is required to fish on lakes or waterways.
M. Fire And Open Burning:
1. No open burning allowed.
2. Fires allowed only in grills that are utilized for cooking purposes and must be extinguished before leaving. (Ord. 2013-21, 7-23-2013)
N. Sledding In Miner Park: Sledding in Miner Park is permitted subject to the following conditions:
1. Sledding, snowboarding at own risk.
2. Children under sixteen (16) must be accompanied by an adult.
3. Sledding permitted during daylight hours only.
4. Return to top of hill on outside of designated area.
5. Sledding and snowboarding permitted in fenced area only. (Ord. 2011-46, 12-13-2011; amd. Ord. 2013-21, 7-23-2013)
O. Miner Park Bark Park General Rules And Regulations:
1. Users shall assume all liability and risk related to use.
2. Users are responsible for their dog's behavior.
3. No aggressive dogs.
4. No dogs in heat.
5. Male dogs over six (6) months must be neutered.
6. Dogs may not be left unattended.
7. Dogs must be licensed and vaccinated.
8. Users are responsible for cleaning up after their dog.
9. Small children must be supervised at all times.
10. All village animal regulation ordinances apply. (Ord. 2012-12, 3-13-2012; amd. Ord. 2013-21, 7-23-2013)
7-2-3: LIGHTED ATHLETIC FIELDS AND TENNIS COURTS:
A. Permit Required: Any person or group of persons wishing to use a lighted athletic field for recreational use shall first apply to the public works director
and obtain permission from the village board of trustees.
B. Authority To Operate Lighting System: Only persons designated by the public works director shall be given keys or the means to operate a facility
lighting system. These persons shall be responsible for securing any electrical control panel or building which may be used for such lighting operations
and should be aware of the lighting schedule set out in subsection C of this section. (Ord. 2005-1, 1-11-2005)

allowed:

Second Monday of May to August 31 Sunset to 10:45 P.M.
September through December No use allowed
CITIZENS PARK
January, February and March Sunset to 8:00 P.M.
